review_title: One thumb is up. The other thumb is not down.
pros: It's a reasonably ethical place that does reasonably ethical work and that treats its employees reasonably well.
cons: There are two tracks at AIR that never quite meet: the full-tilt emphasis on DEI and on winning new contract work. The constant re-organization into different subgroups can also distract you from your work, as can the constant changes in and compliance with the performance review system. Is this just how white collar businesses operate in the 21st century? Perhaps.

review_title: Be Forewarned - Go In with Your Eyes Open
pros: Good benefits, most (not all) staff are generally easy to work with
cons: Agree with other comments describing mass exodus of employees, inequities among salaries for comparable skill sets and credentials, and leadership that is uncommunicative and out-of-touch with the experiences of staff. (*Note to Readers: Even for the 4- and 5-star ratings, read the 'Cons' sections carefully…definitely some common themes that keep emerging…) At the time of this writing, just within my division, I am seeing about one person every other week leave the organization (granted, AIR is a large organization but still…I don’t know that new hires are enough to keep up with the vacuum that is being created). Organizational culture tends to promote getting ahead by competition, instead of collaboration; perhaps partly because pathways for advancement are not transparent and people think this is the only way to get ahead. Leadership does not hold toxic employees accountable, and as a result, bad behavior is tolerated and perpetuated. There may be a few in leadership who want to strive for change…but the question is are they willing to get their hands dirty to create impact, and in particular to create enough impact to turn the tide of people leaving?

pros: I was easily able to get support from my manager when I decided to go to grad school, for which I will get a portion of the tuition reimbursed. I have never worked with a group of more dedicated and professional people, who are also kind and helpful.
cons: Communication from leadership isn't always the best. It's easy to feel disconnected from what's going on at the highest levels. PTO not as generous as I was lead to believe, but not terrible.

review_title: Mission Applies to Everyone but AIR Employees
pros:
- Flexibility in terms of schedule
- There are some really great people there--just not those in higher-level/leadership positions
cons:
AIR is a non-profit organization that combines the worst of higher education and the worst of organization/business into one entity. 

AIR touts work/life balance, but doesn't actually provide you any. Projects and proposals always come first. Sure, you can take PTO, but no one is there to pick up your workload while you're out, so you come back to double the work. 

AIR touts diversity, equity, and inclusion but NEVER considers the power dynamics at play within the organization. They fund "pet projects" (i.e., projects that interest those in C-suite level positions) to show how invested in DEI they are rather than investing in their people. Inequities, especially in terms of salary and opportunity are rampant within the organization.  Additionally, the DEI efforts do not take into consideration the needs of employees with disabilities. Sure, there is the option for someone to self-disclose and request accommodations, but in terms of valuing the perspectives and experiences of those with disabilities, perspectives of other groups are valued higher. If your "slice" of the DEI "pie" isn't  visible, you don't matter. 

Junior level staff are overworked, underappreciated, and viewed by those in higher positions as disposable. They are often relegated to mundane tasks that don't afford them an opportunity to grow. 

The work within the organization is incredibly siloed, which perpetuates those from different divisions constantly reinventing the wheel. 

Research projects deemed "rigorous" by those in higher-level positions are considered more valuable and important than any other type of work the organization does--even if other projects bring in the same monetary award to the company. 

Human Resources claim that they are there to support employees, but fail to recognize the role that they play in perpetuating the power imbalances. They take a reactive, rather than proactive, approach to supporting disagreements in the workplace. 

If you're a client, expect an incredibly high overhead rate and fee applied to your contract!

pros: Flexible work schedule provided good work-life balance
cons: The pay is extremely low compared to AIR’s competitors (my new position was able to offer a 50% salary increase from what I received at AIR). Worse than the low pay is the way that researchers and research associates are treated by leadership.  If you rank below a managing researcher at AIR, you are 100% expendable and will be treated as such. And don’t forget about the sexism—It is well known that David Myers has a record of entering town hall meetings and immediately pointing at (high ranking) women to take notes. My team was able to document and report incidences of prejudiced and discriminatory actions by practice area leaders, which were reported to Human Resources. Human Resources did nothing and other practice area leaders, who were fully aware of these actions and were on many calls when these discriminatory actions took place, did nothing to address the issue. Instead of taking action, some leaders were even promoted during this time period despite the many documented complaints against them.  It’s laughable that AIR is now advertising their efforts to promote health equity and diversity while they wholly ignore the treatment of lower level staff by leadership. Talk is cheap, and so is AIR.

review_title: Good place to start in social science research right out of undergrad
pros: Good opportunities for young talent to work on a wide variety of projects across multiple disciplines; opportunities to learn skills in-house through on-the-job training, professional development workshops, and invited speakers; many higher-level staff (e.g., managing directors, principal researchers, and researchers) are willing to mentor junior staff and provide specific work opportunities (e.g., publishing, stats work, data collection, etc.) that will advance one's career and possibly prepare them for graduate school. Many junior staff continue to rise through the ranks or are admitted to prestigious graduate programs.
cons: Some staff I knew complained of low pay and lots of menial tasks. This wasn't my experience and although there were some teams that truly didn't value young talent, I found that many who had a negative experience simply didn't advocate for themselves enough. I found that most who did advocate for themselves were able to find interesting and engaging work, and good mentorship. In 2013, when I started RA pay was only about $35k, rising to $40k, and eventually associate pay was somewhere close to $45-50, but it looks like perhaps pay has since gone up, which is a good direction for the company to take.

review_title: If you love yourself don't apply here!
pros: No pros, if I could give it 0 stars I would have.
cons:
From my experience there were very few good people at this organization: most were horrible. It seemed to me that lower ranked employees can often be disrespected and mistreated. If you care about your mental health avoid this place at all costs. It was my understanding that most Research Assistants there were constantly on the look for a job in hopes of leaving the place. It was very hard for me to find learning opportunities unless I pushed hard for them, and at least while I was there, there was barely any in person skill-based training for Research Assistants. Seeing where some of the former Researcher Assistants ended up post AIR, it seems that the exit opportunities suck for most Research Assistants. I felt miserable and unappreciated working there because of the low salary and bad treatment. Unless you're becoming homeless if you pass on working at AIR I would recommend you never consider this place. 
Note: If you do apply, expect to get a taste of how they treat their employees from the recruitment process where candidates can be ignored for weeks by recruiters and at times even months before the company finalizes an offer.

pros:
1. You get to work with some really amazing and inspiring individuals.
2.  Meaningful and interesting work.
3.  Great benefits.
4.  Nice offices.
cons:
I can't comment on the assessment work, but the professional services side of the business has been suffering from a slow and steady decline for years.  You can feel this stagnation 
 all through the organization, and morale has really taken a hit.  

The CEO reorganized the company structure a few years ago.  This has yielded few, if any, tangible benefits. He is now touting a new strategic plan which, based on early indications, is an approach he openly ridiculed in years past.  It's obvious to everyone that there's no real hope of growing the work.  Layoffs will no doubt continue to occur just as they've occured over the past few years.  Promotion opportunities will continue to be few and far between for us.

I know this comes off as a hit on the CEO and his executive team.  It is not.  They are an intelligent and well intentioned group. They're not the most charasmatic and inspiring people, but they are competant and professional.   It is just clear to everyone they have no idea how to right the ship.  If they did, they would have done it long ago.

pros:
- Opportunity to get your feet wet in research directly out of school.

- Many well-regarded researchers and PIs in the field to potentially meet and work alongside. 

- A solid 401k matching program (for senior staff who can afford to set aside their pay).
cons:
- Junior staff are often pushed beyond what is reasonable for their modest pay, which is middling within the industry.  

- Virtually no opportunity to work your way up without pursuing an advanced graduate degree. This is on top of an absurd seat-time requirement for promotion which creates and artificial 2-year barrier for junior staff. A bit rich coming from an organization whose own research touts the advantages a competency-based approach to demonstrating skill and mastery of content...

- Absolute lack of cohesive management across the organization. You have to cross your fingers and hope you get paired with a staff manager that advocates on your behalf, or suffer at the hands of pure researchers that view their role as more babysitter than mentor. Think about the crappy prof you had that was forced to teach as part of their tenure track and that's the level of indifference.

review_title: It's what you make of it
pros:
-I get to work with some really awesome people
-Lots of opportunities for finding mentors and learning new skills
-Some projects have opportunities for travel, but not so often that it would be a burden
-A huge range of different projects you can work on. If you're vocal early on you can network yourself onto projects in topics you're interested and that focus on skills you want to grow in
-Good benefits, lots of flexibility for work schedule, working from home etc.
-Lots of independence
-People are very approachable--happy to offer help, advice, and friendship
-Lack of structure can feel like either a curse or a blessing. If you're clear with yourself about what you want to get out of your time at AIR, and if you're willing to show the initiative, you can make it happen
cons:
-Very hierarchical in terms of career path, need a masters to move up to Associate and terminal degree (PhD typically) for Researcher or higher. They offer tuition assistance though.
-Downside of flexibility is that the office can feel kind of dead sometimes. But junior staff are always around, so it's easy to make friends
-Getting onto projects can be a little stressful in the beginning
-Pay is kind of low, but not unusual for starter non-profit salaries. It's perfectly adequate for single living in DC with student loans

Too bad - the knowledge sharing could have been amazing. 
Benefits are, again, better than some, worse than others.

review_title: Fine first job out of Grad school
pros: Bagel Wednesdays and Friendly Staff
cons: Hard to move up in the organization.

pros: wonderful mission, interesting projects, great people
cons: low pay and not easy to promote at low levels

review_title: Great non-profit; mission driven; solid benefits; few mgmt issues
pros:
I love that AIR is big enough that it has solid infrastructure supports (IT, facilities, HR, etc) which many non-profits skimp on by necessity. I have found staff to be very mission-driven. Everyone is really focused on the goals of our projects and improve people's lives. Benefits are really good for a non-profit. Health Insurance isn't great, but  it's not the worst I have seen. It's a very fast-paced work environment and there is a lot of flexibility so long as you're getting your work done. Competitive salary and bonus structure. 

One of my favorite things is that AIR is very supportive of career/professional development. Lots of opportunities to learn new content and skills on the job. Lots of supports from AIR for learning outside the organization, too. Staff here love learning.
cons:
The leadership have some issues with communication and transparency. They made good decisions, but then communicate poorly to the staff about the changes which has created a rift between staff and leadserhip and breads distrust. Leadership are aware of this and it appears as though they want to change, but so far it's been more lip service than anything. 

There can be issues with work/life balance if an employee isn't used to setting boundaries and advocating for themself. It's not a huge fight to obtain balance, in fact, managers are responsive to complaints about workload, but it's incumbent on the employee to let their manager know where the line is. I've observed that this is harder for the most junior staff to navigate.

review_title: Good overall, but varies widely from team to team
pros:
~ The company means well, and seems to believe in their mission statements.  
~ Staff members get systematic annual appraisals, which aren't perfect (although they get overhauled every few years), but which probably make for fairer assessments than less structured appraisals.  AIR also gives annual raises for inflation, and has percentage-based merit raises.
~ Each staff member is assigned a "staff manager"/mentor; the manager exists to advocate the staff member and to monitor the staff member's performance.  The quality & motivation of these varies. 

~ The benefits are good and maternity leave is generous.  Offices often (perhaps always?) include a room that new mothers can use, and the ones I've seen have even included a mini-fridge.
~ Although the quality of I.T. support is generally very good.  My experiences at 3 smaller offices have been largely very good, and my experiences with the central I.T. help line staff have usually been very good.
cons:
~ Job satisfaction varies widely depending on teams/bosses.  Work-life balance varies widely depending on supervisors/bosses and seniority level.
~ The apparent quality of HR support dropped off hugely a few years ago (maybe 2012 or 2011?), with the larger offices not having a clearly assigned office liaison.  Lower-level staff hired before ~2013 are underpaid, having been hired before AIR offered a competitive entry-level salary.
~ Charge codes aren't available for everything (e.g., parties, cross-team work groups, mandatory staff management meetings), which means staff sometimes need to work longer days to offset the time taken for work-related functions.

pros: I love it here. Flexible work hours. Supportive Staff. Great CEO and Department heads.
cons: I miss being in the office with my colleagues.

review_title: Pretty bad if you don't have a PhD
pros:
-There are some very bright, motivated, and inspiring people who work here.
-Many RAs form a tight-knit group
-Commuting benefit was nice
-From what I hear, a very good place to work if you have a related PhD and want to conduct applied research
-Georgetown office location is quite nice, though I hear they're looking to move to the suburbs.
cons:
-Absolutely no room for advancement, unless you consider leaving to pursue your PhD and applying for a job at a higher level to be room for advancement.
-Very poor, uncompetitive pay for research assistants/research analysts
-Many people who are forced into manager roles are actually very, very bad at being managers
-Work/life balance uneven, in my experience. Sometimes you struggle to fill all 40 hours of work, other times you work 60 hours per week (but of course you are only allowed to bill 40!).
-Sometimes you do interesting tasks on interesting projects, other times you do mind-numbingly boring tasks on mind-numbingly boring projects. You have absolutely no say in which projects you're assigned to.
-Compensation, promotions, raises, and bonuses are completely disconnected from performance. Outstanding work does not correlate to higher raises, bonuses, or promotions.

pros: Company culture is healthy for the most part. The benefits and perks are decent.
cons: Staff manager structure and hard to get promoted

pros: AIR is a great place for early career research experience. There are many opportunities to work with senior level researchers and contribute to annual statistical reports.
cons: Some senior staff have unreasonable expectations with deadlines in order to please the clients, which can lead to burn-out.

review_title: Management and the board should be ashamed.
pros: Benefits are good.  You get to telecommute (officially 3 days a week, though most people take 5, because no one really manages anyone around here).
cons:
*Most offices are ghost towns.   
*There is no company culture.  
*Turnover is ridiculously high.  
 *There are way too many VPs and equivalents.   *Professional Services revenue has been flat for years.  
*Nobody at the Executive level is competent enough to run a Taco Bell, much less a company of this size.  Honestly, not even our CEO would be more than a mid-level manager at a Fortune 500 company.  
*The only high growth, financially sound element of this company (which, no surprise, was not overseen by the CEO) is currently being sold off as "we don't know how to successfully grow it further".  Of course, under that logic, we should sell everything. I'm not sure what the CEO's job is, but I'm guessing growing the company is a kind of a big part of it.

review_title: Avoid this fraudulent slave-hole at all costs
pros: - Free bagels on Wednesdays
cons:
- My first day of work? The phone was up-side-down, disconnected, and my monitor was shoved into the corner, face down. It looked like someone had taken a giant dump on my desk. A perfect summation of what AIR is all about

- Runs like a mafia slave shop full of foreign workers

- Managers are at liberty to use bullying tactics & vile language whenever they wish

- Upper management has absolutely no clue about what's really going on

- Pay is 15-20% under market rate

- Gossip, politics, favoritism, prejudice, bias, discrimination, run rampant despite AIR's weak attempts to pretend like they care about fake issues like diversity, inclusion, etc

- AIR is in the testing scam business -- an industry sucking in billions and billions each year. Kids are over-tested and under-taught. No wonder our country keeps falling behind every year even though billions and billions are spent on "education" and "testing"

- AIR runs like any other disgusting, money-hungry, corporation; but it cloaks itself under guise of a do-gooder "non-profit"

- Stay away from this giant stink-hole, where your career will go to die, and where you will be treated like an animal, with no dignity or equity

pros:
1. Huge intellectual capital
2. Great benefits, perks and fair salary for nonprofit
3. Lots of social opportunities
4. Laid back office culture (in terms of dress and office hours)
5. Contributions to many fields are progressive and positive. A place to make a difference.
cons:
Almost all of the Pros are undermined by:
1. A culture of blame and finger pointing when collective mistakes are made (leaders blaming field staff, field staff blaming leaders, everyone blaming clients.)
2. Very slick "Forest" people who leave it to the "Tree" people to deliver too-good-to-be-true promises and client pitches. 
3. An employee review process that is less about self improvement and more about creating goals that present the perception of performance vs actual, day-to-day performance.
4. A circling of the wagons (backstabbing, rumors, sabotaging) around employees who are different.
5. Not walking the talk regarding work-life balance: it's never a good sign when a project leader "jokes" about being too dedicated to take vacations, e-mails during his/her PTO and late at night, brags about working late at night and on weekends, and then claims family first.

pros: None, awful place to work at
cons: Impossible to grow, work goes to "who knows you better" rather than who works hard for it

review_title: Non profit that doesn't care about employees
pros: - Wednesday bagels for breakfast
cons:
- Management is awful - they do not take time to train new employees and then wonder why they may not be performing to par a few months later.  I never had a review during my entire time there.  They say they care about their employees but they really do not.  They only care about deadlines and if they do not get sued by various states/territories they work with.  
- There is no/little interaction with other departments in your division.  Everyone does their own thing without consulting other departments.  Various departments won't tell others what they do and then you never know what is going on without that information.  Departments also will miss key deadlines which puts your work in jeopardy and you will get blamed instead of the department that missed their deadline.
- Employees are there for their job and not for each other.  Staff interaction is very low and makes it a depressing place to work.
- They hire a lot of temps who hardly ever get hired but are told they might - it makes it hard for full time staff and temps who are so eager but quickly realize there is little to no chance of getting a full time or even part time permanent position

review_title: Friendly coworkers, caring staff managers, low pay
pros:
I really love working here. Coworkers are pretty friendly towards each other. They are the type of people you also want to hang out with outside the workplace. 

Projects are also very interesting. The projects allow for personal growth and development. The staff manager that you usually are paired up with is one who pretty much lines up with what you'd like to tailor your career path. 

Depending on who your project director is, it is also nice to be able to purchase books for your own personal development (as long as the book is relevant to your project).

The company has pretty good benefits (health, dental, and vision). The premium you pay is pretty low compared to other companies. They have an annual gala where everyone dress up. They also give out tickets for a Nationals game each year.
cons:
Research assistants and research associates are not paid very well compared to others in the industry (even when compared to other non-profits). Promotions are not just based on merit- it also depends on how long you've put in your time and it also depends on your credentials. 

It's also very hard to climb the ladder because there are only a few levels to climb. A few people have been stuck as a research associate or researcher without being promoted for a long time.

review_title: Not as great as it once was
pros: Great, smart, motivated colleagues. Good benefits, somewhat flexible telework policies, interesting work. AIR gets some of the best and brightest in the social sciences -- from entry level to top management. They have an extremely successful track record of getting grants and contracts from the federal government as well as the private sector, which leads to a wide variety of projects.
cons: It seems as though they are getting too large, with too many managers/VPs at the top. The near constant "reorganizing" efforts are tiresome and unclear to most staff. Most of the top project leaders (managing directors, etc) are so expensive that their projects cannot afford to have them staffed at workable levels. Its often not clear to employees what it is that top level people actually do. People are definitely getting away with just skating by while collecting enormous salaries, but as long as you are fully staffed and getting good annual reviews, no one seems to care.

job_title: Research Analyst in Silver Spring, MD
pros: You have your own office. You can close the door if you have noisy neighbors.
cons:
- Rampant favoritism in the Health Program. Promotion is not merit-based. 
- Most members of senior leadership of the Health Program lack experience in quantitative policy research and are uninformed about current health policy issues. One senior manager (who is not a native speaker of English) has a shaky grasp of the English grammar and often wrote emails that didn't make sense at all. Another senior manager has no research experience to speak off, but she was repeated proposed as project director simply because all she did was to name-drop powerful people she claimed she knew.
- Senior leadership lacks professionalism in their treatment of junior and mid-level staff. 
- Very tedious work. It is doubtful whether AIR's works have any policy consequences at all.
- Senior leadership refuses to invest in staff's job training, even on skill sets that are central to the staff's works.
- There is a lack of collegiality. People are reluctant to chat with you even if you reach out, unless you have the same charge codes with them.

SMH.
they have contracting companies to look for people for them and they lie to the recruiters and by the time u get in you are stock until you find your way out. nothing to learn, you work like a Hebrew slave and they pay u peanuts , and nothing to show for it. and no one appreciates you.

job_title: Lead Software Engineer in Naperville, IL
pros: meaningful job towards education for K-12 students
cons: hard to get career growth in senior position

review_title: A very interesting hybrid of strong nonprofit mission with corporate structure
pros: Excellent benefits, flexible schedules and an understanding of work-life balance; strong dedication to mission - although you may be doing business-like work it is always focused on the desire to make good change in the world.  My salary is excellent compared to traditional nonprofits (although it sounds like the entry-level positions less so).  Have always had lots of opportunity for professional development.  Enjoy working with professional, nice people across the org here and in other offices.
cons: Some of the programs are more difficult to work with than others.  A lot of the negative reviews here sound like they are from people working in one particular program that has a reputation for not valuing its people, requiring long hours and having poor management.  BUT, the other programs and the administrative units have some really good people, good management, and good opportunities for advancement.  If you are interviewing here you just need to keep that in mind and try to get a feel for the personality and management style of the group you'd be working in.

review_title: Great team spirit, great learning opportunity
pros: They have a technical adviser/mentorship program
cons: Does not pay really well

pros: Great benefits. Nice working environment. Potential for internal promotions.
cons: Lacks goal and employee development process.

pros: Nice coworkers, flexible hours and travel
cons: Salary Is low, not many in office workers

review_title: High Stress, Low Pay, No Growth!
pros: Aside from few bad apples, majority of those I worked directly with were really great people who care about me personally and professionally.
cons:
Work hours within Assessment are unacceptable. I was repeatedly asked to work nights, weekends, and even holidays. 
 
If you join AIR as a Junior level employee with a Bachelor's degree there is a high likelihood that you will never be anything other than a Junior level employee. In my experience it did not matter how hard you worked, if you earned an advanced degree or certificate outside of work, or if you repeatedly exceeded your job duties/expectations. At the end of the day they have an unreasonable promotion schedule by which it can take many many years to move up to a mid level employee. Quite literally I worked with people who had been with the company 5-10 year that were still [generally] in the same position as when they started.

review_title: Maybe hold off for a bit.
pros: Smart colleagues.  Interesting work.  Flexible work arrangements, though work-life balance can be a bit tough sometimes.  It's definitely not a horrible place to be.
cons: The organization lacks a cohesive feel.   I don't think there are many staff here who feel any sort of emotional connection to AIR, like you see in many companies.

review_title: Antisocial and toxic company culture, no room for growth
pros:
Flexible hours/work from home policy
Earn decent entry-level experience
cons:
Where to begin?

- antisocial office culture (office is closed off, people lock themselves in their offices and don't socialize, you only know the people you work with on projects, which are not necessarily the people you physically work near)

- incredibly hierarchical (by policy, they will not promote Research Assistants without a Master's degree, although they seem to intentionally hide this fact during recruitment; level of education is taken incredibly seriously, letters after someone's name mean much more than the quality of their work; certain project directors/senior leaders have a reputation for rudeness/inappropriateness that is tolerated due to their rank/prestige of their work; bloated and well-paid senior management despite continued cuts to employee perks/social activities)

- high-stakes/punitive work culture (the industry has become increasingly competitive as available work decreases, causing leaders to be harsh and unforgiving around proposal/project loss and/or errors in client deliverables, with no support or understanding for how to improve project work)

- decentralized, siloed structure leads to inefficiency, disorganization, and isolation

- mission is totally disconnected from the work, it's at best lip service

job_title: Senior Research Scientist in Washington, DC
pros: Well trained and motivated human capital is a sign of a quality organization. AIR has some great employees who care about the work that is done with an eye toward improving the health, education, and welfare of people.
cons:
During my time at AIR, I witnessed countless examples of people being pushed to charge their time to projects, regardless of actual effort dedicated to the project. AIR has a large upper management structure that is well compensated. Hence, the management machine must be fed. 

People working on projects are encouraged to maximize hours charged clients. It's hard to see the value of some managers who don't know much about the actual work. They do know how to push lower level employees to bill for their work. Furthermore, entry level staff are often put in positions where they must learn on the job and charge clients for their "on the job" training. Rather than hire people who fit the work to be done, it's often an effort to see who's available and stick them in the position.

job_title: Test Developer I in Washington, DC
pros:
AIR is an amazing company to work for:
1-Competitive Salary
2-Amazing benefits package
-a-Automatic retirement savings without needing employee match
-b-17 Days PTO for new employees
-c-Tuition Assistance for further education
-d-Very reasonably priced healthcare options
-e- Public transportation subsidy
3-Qualifying non-profit for 10 year service student loan forgiveness
4-Intelligent and Educated coworkers
cons:
A large portion of employee compensation is tied up in the benefits package; great for the financially secure, makes it difficult to make ends meet for those with large college debts or new families or both.

 Assessment division requires specific skill set not readily obtainable in similar fields, or through formal education;  not the best fit for everyone.

Due to the number of offices across the country, along with many  employees working from home,  human interaction within a team can be lacking.  Feels like coming into the office is not much different from telecommuting, but telecommuting is not an option for most employees.

DC  cost of living is very high.

review_title: You have an opportunity to grow your own work and work with talented people.
job_title: Senior Consultant in New Orleans, LA
pros: I really loved the excellent benefits and great flexibility.
cons: There is no work-life balance. The company has a business model that makes life very stressful. You are constantly having to look for work projects unless you are in the clique.  The percentage of time for each project is too small and unrealistic, which contributes to a poor work-life balance. In this way you are actually working for free. The company is also very top heavy with over paid upper management staff who are out of touch with staff.  There is no transparency, so you have to be able to read between the lines.  The company is a revolving door. There are always lay-offs or employees leaving for whatever reason. The organizational structure is confusing. The company boasts of its promotion of diversity, but it really doesn’t do a good job in this area.

review_title: Think twice before accepting a job at AIR
job_title: Test Development Specialist in Washington, DC
pros: The location of their HQ--Georgetown--can't be beat. Salaries are competitive, and there are many bright, engaging people there. Those in the In-Crowd are well rewarded.
cons:
I don't know about other divisions (I've heard they're much better), but the assessment division has a well-deserved reputation for being extremely oppressive and unfair to employees. (Turnover is very high.) There is a definite "in-crowd" mentality, overtly stated as, "if you want to be successful here, you have to know how to / be willing to socialize appropriately" (i.e., you will be rewarded for your ability to endure and enjoy late-night gatherings with management). Those whose first obligation is to family or to a good night's sleep are penalized accordingly. Good performance is rewarded only for those in this in-crowd. With very few exceptions, excellent performance evaluations do not translate into raises or promotions for those unwilling to conform. And like many other places with an academic bent, pedigree is paramount. A degree from a top college or university carries much more weight than years of experience and good work, even when the over-pedigreed are under-performing. 

Unrealistic timelines and very tight budgets contribute to the high levels of frustration.

review_title: Exciting, interesting, and important work; smart people, but senior management needs improvement.
pros: Great, intelligent, and diverse co-workers make daily experiences interesting and challenging. Excellent flexibility with work hours and remote working situations. Very good salary and benefits.
cons:
Very often, work hours border the insane. You could easily be working 60-80 hour workweeks for an extended basis while of course only being able to "log" 40 hours per week.
Some managers don't seem to grok the concept of Rewards and Recognition. They're quick to criticize, but hardly ever pause to say "thanks for working the entire weekend" or "good job resolving that issue."
Often, lack of resource planning/allocation causes significant shortages once the project goes operational.

review_title: Ever try eating soup with a knife? Now imagine the soup tastes like sewer water and bleach..
job_title: No One of Any Particular Importance
pros: Benefits are ok, some locations you get your own office apparently,laptop was decent, holiday party was nice. Worked with some very bright people. If you enter the company at a high enough level, you can lock in for the long haul judging by the length of tenures of some. Folks in DC seem to like the locale.
cons:
Directionless unimaginative task oriented work, very stagnant culture, little incentive to excel since promotion is so rare, talents appear to waste horribly, exceptional lack of transparency at the senior strategic management level, non-productive competitiveness, lack of business development foresight, quite gossipy, lack of consistency as to how rules are applied, lack of clarity and consistency on key policies, experience will vary 
greatly by project.  It is easy to be sucked into the "potential" of what could be early on.

review_title: A place to end up, not to start
pros:
- some great managers
- good benefits
- interesting work, if you have luck

Can be very good work if you end up on the right projects with the right project directors. Unfortunately assignments are made based on staff availability, not interests or qualifications. Timing is everything here. 

Difficult to advance from within but a great deal if you are going in as a senior manager. More flexibility in which assignments you work on, based on your experience.
cons:
- extremely low pay
- no checks and balances system on sr. mgmt
- not very fair, different rules for different employees

The pay is offensive. You can make 25-35% more at a similar company. No negotiating power unless you have a salary history, even then they might not be able to accommodate you.

How well you fare depends on how much your supervisor advocates for you/how well they are liked by senior mgmt.

review_title: Dysfunctional and dishonest upper management and HR. Sad, because so many good people work there.
pros:
Different projects going on and diverse, so opportunities for any type of researcher to find interesting work.
Most researchers care about their work and their heart is in the right place.
Most business development staffers easy to work with
cons:
HR is dishonest, only concerned about keeping salaries down. Will ignore you even when management asks them to help you.
Communication is absolutely horrible. HR does not communicate with management, management does not communicate with researchers, and lead researchers do not communicate with project staff. Lead researchers and management have too much on their plate and compensate by not spending time talking with project staff -- even about project work.
Collaboration is nearly nonexistent. People close office doors and work on their own.
Staff development hampered by poor communication and collaboration. You must self-teach to learn anything.
Many staff are passive-aggressive and insecure. Problems don't get resolved, instead people just leave.
HR and management do not try to find work for staff when projects end, Instead HR tries to get rid of staff and hire new staff for new projects.
In sum, it's the bureaucracy of the federal government, the formal culture of corporate America and the pay of a small non-profit.

review_title: Quality of Job Varies Greatly by Position, Program, and Level
pros: AIR is doing cutting level research in many areas. It can be an exciting place to work with smart colleagues and the opportunity to learn and increase skills. Benefits are generally good and for people who stay for a while the retirement benefits are particularly generous (AIR's contribution as a percentage of salary goes up with age and time worked at the company). I very seldom get bored working here.
cons: The work experience is very dependent upon the program and the supervisor. I have found it hard to maintain a reasonable work-life balance but I have talked to people in other positions and programs who have not faced this issue. Supervisors have a lot of freedom and some are much better about teaching and mentoring staff than others. Salaries are low for entry level staff and vary greatly for staff in higher level positions. In most job categories there is a glass ceiling unless you have a terminal degree. I feel like we lose a lot of good staff because they develop skills at AIR and then move to another employer where they feel like they have more opportunities to advance.

pros: The benefits are actually very good.  Free bagels and fruit every Wednesday.
cons:
If you are applying for any jobs with Assistant or Associate int he title, don't apply or interview.  You will work LONG hours and not have much of a life.  The higher levels will pass on all their work to you while they do much of nothing.  They are like the 1% here, you, IT, HR, and Facilities are treated like dogs and they will literally look down their noses at you.  They used to do employee surveys to see how people feel about their jobs, they found that the lower levels were so unhappy that they stopped giving them.  Entitlement here is out of control.  The PhDs here think they deserve anything and everything they as for, even if it cannot be done or is with very short notice.

Management doesn't listen much to anyone with new ideas.  If it's not their way, it doesn't get done.

Technology is pretty sub par.  They always seem to be one step behind.  It seems the training and

pros: * Great office location in Georgetown
cons:
* Salaries are significantly below market and management is aware of that 
* Clique-ish, rampant favoritism
* Merit-based promotions are rare (please keep in mind this is an observation, since I was promoted, but many who deserved were not)
* Long periods between promotions
* Excellence is discouraged, mediocrity and following orders is rewarded
* Management is not technical or competent enough to understand how an efficient and successful engineering organization should work and thrive
* Rudeness is tolerated and in some cases - encouraged
* VPs of Assessment appear either oblivious to the widespread dissatisfaction or simply don't care
* As the job market improves and competent employees do not accept offers from AIR, or leave AIR, more and more work visa individuals are hired at low salaries, which creates an odd culture focused on keeping immigration status, rather than doing a great job for an organization they love.

pros: Friendly collaborative work culture, flexible hours, casual dress code, low stress if you're active about managing your work but can be high stress if you aren't.
cons:
Lack of career growth opportunities

Relatively low pay compared to similar positions in same industry

Requests by higher level staff to do admin work outside of normal project functions

Occasionally disorganized leadership due to how projects are structured (you have multiple bosses who each have multiple bosses), and the company's policy of underfunding projects in an effort to underbid competitors (which leads to staff working a lot of unpaid overtime and conflicting messages about how to allocate your time).

The expectation is that new hires will leave in 2 years so there isn't much effort made into retaining lower level staff. A promotion does not lead to much higher pay at lower levels, seems to be based mostly on time served, and without a graduate degree there is nowhere to grow after you obtain it. The lack of incentives to work hard leads to low motivation/morale.

review_title: Good job to start your career, very little upward mobility
job_title: Research Assistant in Crystal City, VA
pros:
Like most RA jobs, you do boring work for researchers, BUT there is opportunity to work on your own research projects, author papers, and present at conferences (you have to be proactive and search for these opportunities).
You rarely have to work more than 9 - 5. They have to pay you overtime if you work more than 40 hours a week, so they rarely have you work more than 40 hours a week.
cons:
Very little room to move up for RAs. It seems like their current business model is to hire RAs out of college and pay them a RA salary and wait for them to leave the company. Most RAs leave after 2 years because they make it hard to get promoted. 
Promotions are based on years of experience, has little to do with performance.
There are great senior leaders and project directors and there are terrible senior leaders and project directors.

review_title: Psychometric Support Assistant - do not take this job
job_title: Psychometric Support Assistant I in Washington, DC
pros: Decent work life balance most of the year. Summers are very busy, however, so that would be an exception.
cons: Too many to list. Generally you will be underpaid, underappreciated, and overworked. You will be given no formal training and quickly expected to take on A LOT of responsibility that an entry level employee should not have. It takes a full year to get properly trained, but most people leave before 2 full years. The turnover rate is unbelievable which leads to gaps in knowledge. Most people that take this job end up hating it very quickly.

pros: I have had an overall very positive experiencing working at AIR, I enjoy the work, and my co-workers. The organization also has really good benefits, such as PTO that rolls over from year to year with no cap on the amount you can amass.
cons: Some policies related to working from home/ or creating flexible work arrangements for lower tier employees seems arbitrary. A masters degree is also required to advance to the next level which exist as a barrier to growth for some (depending on when you entered the organization).

review_title: Limited career paths and disregard for technical skill restrict opportunities and create inefficiencies.
pros: If you are single, there are many after-hours events to get to know other employees. Also, if you already established in your career with good experience, they pay very well.
cons: If you are just beginning your career (as I was), you will not be paid well. Also, if you have more technical skills, such as programming, you can get into a situation where they need you to use those skills, but do not provide opportunities for advancement in that line of work. The only available career track in my location was as an analyst. It also meant that they had a hard time retaining people with the technical skills they need in their line of work.

review_title: Could be better, could be worse
pros:
Some leaders are very passionate about their work. 
Many of my colleagues are very smart. 
AIR has a diverse range of projects that can provide some variety and interesting work. 
Great benefits. 
Flexibility is great. The most important focus is getting the work done, but you can shape your schedule within reason. 
AIR's HQ is located near the Georgetown waterfront. This is a great area for lunch breaks, especially when the weather is nice.
cons:
Work-life balance is not great, especially for those of us who are willing to work hard. A lot of hours are donated to business development. 
Hit or miss project management can be frustrating. 
While the pay is fair, it is not great. 
It's very difficult to get promoted. 
Very little racial diversity in senior positions.

pros: AIR has good benefits. The company is also very flexible, allowing employees to work from home if needed. Schedules and hours are flexible. This is a great company to work for if you are in school or want to go back; they will work with your school schedule and allow you to adjust your hours. Colleagues are great! Company perks are great.
cons: Employees who work hard and get the job done are the ones who are overworked and not always compensated for their level of effort. Work/life balance is almost non-existent. You will be burned out in the summer during proposal season, so be sure to get your vacation in early. Staff is often stressed out. Senior management has favorites. As long as you have someone in management who has your back, you'll be less likely to be laid off when there are budget cuts or if contracts end and no new work is available.

review_title: Interesting work torpedoed by favoritism and poor management
job_title: Senior Research Analyst in Washington, DC
pros: Most of the people I worked with were great (very bright, committed, and willing to go the extra mile). Offices were really nice and in a great location. In the international department, plenty of opportunities to travel and if a long trip, in business class. The central, senior management were committed to staff development and did a lot to try to foster a fun working environment (Halloween celebrations, big holiday parties, baseball games)
cons: Rampant favoritism in the international department. Many incompetent people were protected and promoted for no other reason except having a good relationship with the VP. A lot of backstabbing and a culture of gossip developed. Many on the senior management team were incompetent and did nothing but complain/gossip.

pros:
Diversity of the work: You can be on a lot of different types of projects (which can also be a con) and this can help you gain different skills and work with various people, rather than being stuck on one project.

Great benefits

If you end up with a manager who cares about you, you will have an incredible experience.
cons:
Management - supposedly this has been a spot for improvement within the organization, but from mine and others' experience, getting placed with a good 'manager/person you report to' was luck of the draw. There seemed to be a fair amount of people who did not have the skills for being a mentor and really needed come training; while some others excelled at it.

Work-life balance could be terrible depending on the project/project leader.

pros: Great location in Georgetown. Flexibility to work from home depending on your manager. Many positions are remote. The benefits are decent and they have events that keep employees engaged (Ice cream socials, holiday parties, Pi day, happy hour, etc.). There's a mix of independent and collaborative work.  If you work on site at any of the offices, there's usually a bagel or a donut day.
cons: The assessment division of AIR continues to grow, but many of the test development staff are over worked due to this growth. The turnover is pretty high, and there is little to no training for new hires.  Some managers play favorites, so if you aren't on their good side forget about any significant raise or promotion.

review_title: Positive work environment, stable job for artists!
pros: Managers treat employees with kindness and respect. Coworkers treat each other with respect, and they do stay true to promoting the 'AIR values' of diversity and inclusion at least in my personal experience. For an artist, this is an amazing job! Stable, and with a decent salary + benefits! Also very flexible  about 'working from home' arrangements.
cons: In my experience, do not expect any massive pay bumps. AIR is an non-profit, so if a rapidly increasing salary is what you're after, this might not be a good fit. And I would like to emphasize that this 'con' is not a fault of AIR, but more of a warning about what to expect.

review_title: If you value your intelligence, don't work here
pros: Free drinks like coffee, tea, sodas (all the time) and free bagels on Wednesday. Co-workers are really really nice and if management is not there, it is generally pleasurable.
cons:
-Intelligence is not valued (in fact, you're actively discouraged from speaking on your background expertise) 
- Conflicting management styles (one supervisor will tell you something, co-workers will do something else, and you'll get yelled at for what the other supervisor told you to do)
- No clear onboarding structure
- Get verbally abused for first-time offenses 
- Long commute if not around the area (and not easily metro accessible)
- Cutthroat environment (only by the management) 
- Can get busy very quickly
- Encouraged to take on more assignments, but it's not sustainable (always adding more work with not enough being removed)

review_title: Overall great company - but it all depends who your boss(es) and what department you're in
pros:
Many social events throughout the year
Good paid time off schedule
Wonderful office location ( The HQ )
Small gym with showers, etc ( The HQ )
Very cheap parking
Comparatively cheap medical / dental benefits
Relaxed dress code
Young staff environment
Sports teams
cons:
The department and time I was at AIR allowed me to advance quickly and work on and learn new things often. However from my co-workers I know other areas of the company it was very hard to get promoted or a raise, and that they were over-stressed and worked. 

I can say as a whole the company provided me a very positive experience, but for others I understand and can agree with their complaints of departments that I did not work in.

review_title: Challenging work, great colleagues--but low pay"
pros:
At AIR you get to work with talented, intelligent people with diverse expertise on a daily basis.  You are constantly learning from others.  Although it really varies depending on who your manager is, some managers are really great at providing opportunities for career development. 

The work is intellectually stimulating and at times can be fun.  

The benefits are decent and the flexible work day is a nice perk.
cons:
Salaries for research assistants and research associates are too low.  Most research associates have Master's degrees and pay ranges from 45,000 to 55,000.  \

Many divisions have too much work for the number of people working.  Some employees have been able to implement a work-life balance, but overall people do not have work-life balance.

review_title: Getting ahead depends on who you know rather than performance
pros: With offices around the country, everyone is used to having to work with staff that is located remotely, so the infrastructure is in place for when I need to telecommute. This allows for a better work-life balance.
cons: It's not an equal playing field. Recognition and promotion depends on who your staff manager is and who you know. When AIR acquired one company a few years ago, all new staff from that company automatically received a promotion of a level or two, so that people that came in from the new company with only a couple of years experience out of college were on par with people who had that same number of years of experience and a Ph.D. because the new VP pushed for them.

review_title: Not a place for career development
pros: It is laid back, and most of people are easy to work with.
cons: If you look for a place for career development, this is not the place for you. Seniors or managers don't really care about your career path, and just ask you to do the work whenever they need. You might have strong technical skill, but they often give you administrative work to do without asking your interest. And then at the end of year, they come back and tell you that you are not ready for promotion because you didn't make enough contribution to the team....also, your work were not well compensated cause project leaders or seniors took the credit...average salary is so low, compared to other companies. A lot of times, they don't want to increase your salary just so that they can use cheap labor to win the bid. I have seen so many juniors left in a year or two.

review_title: Good colleagues but bloated management, lack of accountability at more snr levels
pros: You get to work with some amazing people - bright, generous, and opportunities can be found if you want to look for them.   AIR does try to provide good work/life balance at least on paper, telecommuting is possible, good overall benefits package, bagel days, fun celebrations to mark holidays of all kinds, as well as events like Pi day or March Madness (or World Cup).
cons: Top level mgmt is bloated due to a restructuring that is still being reworked and reworked.  Focus on the immediate bottomline forces short-sighted decision making.  Snr leadership and snr managers not accountable for how they treat more junior staff and 360 reviews would be illuminating.  Some brilliant people should never direct/manage projects and there is no way to communicate this in a safe and meaningful way.  Some snr staff are incredibly abusive of more junior staff.  Work/life balance can be tough for jnr staff if they feel they can't say no to unrealistic deadlines.  Mentoring of staff can be haphazard depending on who is assigned as a staff manager, or which projects you are assigned.  Furthermore, there is no safe way to communicate concerns of how your needs and management is being handled (a confidential ombudsman would be helpful).  Issues like ethical behavior or violations of policy (e.g. sexual harassment) do have processes and are somewhat successful.  However, if you are with a team, project or manager who are not supportive or effective there is no way to make changes for your own career goals, let alone personal and emotional health. Mobility salary wise is constrained.  A new performance review system provides very little in the way of determining what the it is that needs to be goals.

review_title: Great place, but... what's the point of being loyal?
pros:
This is a great place to work, especially because of the people. The people are definitely what makes me hold on to the organization during times of low morale. 
It is also a great place to be if you have an entrepreneurial spirit, as you can draw your own trajectory and change paths half way. With the caveat that you need a good staff manager to advocate for you. But more often than not, people above you care and advocate for you.
Benefits are good and there is a lot of flexibility in terms of location and schedule. The new offices are really nice, and AIR is not buying into the whole shared space/cubicles culture, allowing most employees to have their own office or share it with one person at most.
cons:
It is virtually impossible for junior staff to move up if they don't have at least a master's degree, even if they're over-performing and have put in many years. Staff with PhDs tend to get more responsibility positions regardless of the experience or previous performance, just because the degree sells better. But often times the work gets down by people who are equally (if not more) capable who don't get the glory.
Compensation: it is good if you start at a mid/senior level and have leverage to negotiate, but not if you work your way up from a junior position. There is no reward for being loyal, other than the increase in PTO and the occasional bonus (unclear who gets these). As you stay in the organization, and especially if you move up quickly (because you're over-performing), your market value decreases dramatically, and it is a long and arduous fight with HR to get you anywhere close to where you should in terms of compensation.

pros:
I work with amazingly smart, friendly people. (Note that it depends where you work in AIR--some divisions like assessment are known snake pits).

Compensation is good and the offices are really nice.
cons: AIR lost a lot of bids, and some good people are getting laid off. Meanwhile, senior leadership is unwilling or unable to communicate what their plan is for keeping the company afloat. No one is addressing the very low morale. Many of us feel like our days are numbered. And when you feel like you're about to get laid off, why bother working hard?

review_title: Tier II System/Net Support, Schools Assessment
job_title: Tier II Systems/Net Support in Lawrenceville, NJ
pros:
Highly professional manager, Tricia Sansevero, very respectful to her about 70 team members staying on top of enormous daily issues.

Hierarchically organized work environment with 4 teams handling incidents reported from schools at 21 states.

Very flexible in terms of allowing you to take few hours time off for your doctor visits, DMV, family emergencies, etc then compensate those hours later on a different shift. 

- Good pay rate
- Spacious office
- Various shifts
- Very nice building in Reston
- Well equipped kitchen with all kinds of coffee, tea, cola, etc.
cons:
This position is a temporary one and they lay off their team members during Summer or low work loads.

I have decided to stay with this contract to end and not leaving it without completing the whole final schools exams but got rewarded eventually by being laid off!

review_title: In the two years I worked there, I never met anyone who respected the top management.
pros: The research projects are engaging, valuable, and interesting.
cons: I worked for a manager who demeaned and criticized her employees in front of the client. She was astonishingly abusive and unprofessional. Several of us complained to HR, but HR seemed to be under pressure to stand behind the manager because she brought in big projects. Her department became a revolving door for new employees who worked for as short a period as possible. We tried to stay for three years so as not to harm our work histories. However,most of us couldn't stick it out for more than a year. It was that bad! I personally knew five people who were traumatized by the whole experience and were upset even after they left because they knew they would never get a good letter of recommendation from the manager.

pros:
- Benefits were great, especially the health care coverage.
- Some of the staff members are great, genuine people.
cons:
- Project enjoyment will vary by client, AIR division, and manager.  I had the particularly frustrating experience of being promised certain projects and work during the hiring phase, only to have these projects largely shelved with me idling by.
- Ideas for generating work were met with some enthusiasm, but I was never given the permission to take any action. 
- Some of the senior staff members, particularly in the health section, are completely self-serving and set everyone else up for failure because they are never around to answer questions, provide guidance, or generally be helpful in any way. And then have the gall to blame everyone else when things go awry. 
- Toxic work environment

pros: AIR is interested in growing employees, so the opportunity for professional development is offered a lot. It's a great place to learn the research ropes, increase skills, and gain experience that can translate into many different areas and types of research. Colleagues are generally intelligent, competent, and passionate about the work. Excellent health and vision benefits.
cons: Office culture varies at the different office locations, so navigating that is tricky at times. Depending on your manager, work life balance can be hard. Promotions and pay raises only happen once a year.

review_title: Great place for researchers, less so for the rest.
job_title: Technical Service Specialist in San Antonio, TX
pros: Filled with smart talented people across all departments.  Competitive salaries and wide range of benefits despite being a non-profit.  Flexible work hours, Teleworking encouraged, and no dress code.
cons: Organization preaches work/life balance and embracing diversity, but they fail to do either.  Everyone is expected to work long hours with little recognition or reward.  Management in my area did more to discourage me than to encourage me.  They also were unable to deal with different personality types very well.  Specifically when dealing with more introverted people.

pros: Opportunities to learn valuable skills, lead tasks, and contribute to reports and proposals; friendly and supportive work environment; flexibility with hours and telecommuting arrangements; perks like free bagels on Wednesdays and annual holiday Gala
cons: Increased responsibility does not lead to adequate promotions and raises-- As a research assistant, I spent a summer correcting incorrect data produced by someone who made 3-4x my salary.  HR limits raises to a certain %, but when you start out as a research assistant making $35,000, it'd difficult to let those raises catch up to the level of work you're doing after a few years. Better to leave and come back with a PhD

pros: You can use your background in analysis.  It is located in DC if you like that.  Many colleagues have advanced degrees.
cons: Don't expect the most job security or the best work-life balance.  You will rarely have the time you need to finish a project. Don't slow down to be thoughtful; on the contrary, hustle and compromise to move constantly forward and brush aside the stress of every present deadlines.  It is not entirely clear how they will maintain your position after a project is completed, though they do what they can. The economic structure of the business has an impact on the workplace quality of life and managerial atmosphere.  AIR is not a think tank; it is a so called  Beltway Bandit, a private company that competes for contracts to maintain itself.

pros: No formal dressing code, company location is good, free ice cream during the summer, free break fast on every Wednesday.
cons: Poor management, no communication with your supervisor, people in management level are very dislike to communicate with you, even say hello in toilet. Supervisor would judge you in silent, no negotiation with lower people when they make decisions secretly. Too many managers doing nothing. Only focus on the result in quantity, careless to the quality. Feels like everyone in here is trying to do as less as they could while getting paid. Above all, ONLY WORKS IN HERE IF YOU ARE DESPERATE. For a few times got a survey from HR with a gift asking how concern if you are leaving here, I guess they also notice that everyone is thinking going somewhere else and trying to keep people here, during my 9 months here, countless of my level people left, my direct supervisor left, 3 managers left.

review_title: Terrible management. No work-life balance. Nice colleagues.
pros: The people I work with are great. At higher levels, there is a lot of flexibility to work at home, as people work with people in other offices.  Benefits are very good.
cons: The management is terrible. There are awful inefficiencies in systems. There is no investing in people. It feels very corporate. People work constantly. Everything that doesn't have a charge code is "extra." That includes things that you still need to do, like meetings with your practice area. I get a lot of requests for responses that need to be turned around in a couple of hours.

job_title: Senior Program Manager in San Antonio, TX
pros: Benefits are good. The company is currently winning business. Good location in Georgetown. Not too much to like here. They market themselves well, and appear fine until you look behind the curtain
cons: Extremely poor leadership. All are so afraid of the Assessment president that they are very dishonest. This is a culture of covering butts and not standing up for employees.  Non-responsive culture and not a team environment at all.  Each man for himself and ugly games are played.  Also, leadership is passive and take no active interest in their employees. Ownership is not taken here, again, because of a culture of fear.  The president uses terrible language and is given to tantrums. His small group of favorites are afraid to go anywhere near employees that he has black balled.

review_title: Wonderful place to work, impossible to move up
pros:
- Flexible hours, work from home, good work/life balance
- Multiple locations around the country and beautiful new offices with sit/stand desks
- Smart coworkers to learn from
- Many staff managers care deeply about their staff
- Professional development budget is great, staff encouraged to attend conferences and classes
- Solid benefits and plenty of vacation days
cons: The major con right now is that you cannot get promoted above Research Assistant without a Master's degree (HR says it's illegal...?). Because of this, all lower level employees have to leave if they want to continue to progress their careers.

pros: Good benefits - which they mention constantly as a response to all the other unprofessional and unethical and unfair activities, and to keep people down.
cons: Horrible, incompetent, and unethical management and leadership.  Egos get in the way of doing good work.  Raises and promotions are based on favoritism and who has sold their soul.  They do not develop current employees but instead hire external people to come in at higher levels.  Work-life balance is a phrase not a practice.  Joke of a reorganization occurring currently.  Just a waste of time and money but won't change what is fundamentally wrong.  The mission is profit for only the highest management. Gave 1 star ratings because those are the lowest available but those are too high.

pros: AIR is a great place to begin a career, it has a lot of young people. It's also a good place to learn team work and basic research skills. The benefits and perks are nice. Location of HQ can't be beat.
cons: There's a real lack of transparency when it comes to salaries and promotions, and it's clear that there's favoritism and friendships play a huge role in getting hired and promoted. The company also suffers from serious lack of diversity. The hours can be brutal and high performers are expected to work until they burnout.

review_title: Honest and Fair Assessment of Information Technology Jobs
job_title: IT Support Specialist in Washington, DC
pros:
I have worked at AIR in an I.T. position for about two years and left on my own. This is not a bitter review but an honest review with no hard feelings, but would like to just  create a warning for anyone considering to accept a contractor position or full time position at AIR.  

There are two groups in I.T. at AIR. The internal support and the IT product support. Internal support consists of many talented employees with multiple certificates and master's degree. The issue in the group is horrible management all around and low compensation. The part I cannot wrap my head around is a group such as facilities is currently being paid more.The IT product support has the similar issue of terrible management but their compensation is very fair with reasonable work hours but tends to consist of majority seasonal positions. 

I started off as a contractor with a promised 6 month to hire conversion timeline. It took over a year to finally be converted due to multiple excuses such as budget or paper work not being processed. Once, I straight up said I will be leaving is when the offer finally came in.The unsettling fact was in the meantime they kept hiring more contractors with higher hourly rates and then once time to be converted I had to straight up say I need this rate or I am leaving tomorrow and many contractors were making 30-40 percent more. The benefits were better at my contracting company and the pay dates and the delay at AIR were a month behind which was unusual and stressful.
cons:
The major issues that created a toxic work environment are these three factors  below:

IT management was horrible from the top. Lower managers who actually cared could not do anything and were treated as puppets. Management is selfish and do not stick up for their employees and do not reward hard workers. If you disagree with anything you are let go without just cause. 

The turnover was the largest  of any company I ever worked. In my group alone it was roughly 20 people in a year. The part I never understand is how top management thought this was acceptable and did not make any changes.

The last part is no raises and promotions were ever carried out. Once you are full time that is your salary and it will not go up. You will work about 50-60 hours minimum a week and not  be rewarded for it.

review_title: I am currently looking for another job.
pros: Flex-Time, laid back dress code, free coffee, decent amount of time off, supervisers who are very understanding, retirement plan is pretty good.
cons: Very hard to get promoted, salary is kind of a joke for me (I have a master's degree, have many student loans, and I live in DC - a very expensive place to live). I have not yet received any kind of bonus. Last year's raise was 4%. Salary inequity - people coming in after me are being offered higher salaries than I was. People with lots of potential and/or master's degrees are tasked with lots of administrative duties.

review_title: Full-time employee for quite some time now
pros:
Great entry level position - good range of experience in tasks and work with a good variety of people and clients.

The dress code is professional but relaxed for the most part. You have opportunities to work closely with teams of people that vary in experience. You are given the amount of work you can handle and then some, so time management is really important. But if you are on top of your work and take on additional work, it is often recognized. Staff is offered good facilities and enough food and drink to keep them happy. In my program, the kinds of work I do is varied, so I feel as though I am learning valuable research skills and working with clients that give me a broader sense of the field.
cons:
People complain of low salary raises, which for the most part is true. Salary adjustments should take into consideration cost of living in the various offices. While people will tell you it's really up to you to advocate as to why you deserve a decent raise, sometimes it really comes down to luck and politics. People who are severely overworked can receive measly 1-2% raises, while others miraculously receive the rare higher raises. 

Turnover is ridiculously high at almost every level. It seems every month, there are a handful of staff that leave the company. There are very apparent glass ceilings. While some upper management denies it, junior level staff are essentially replaceable as they expect you to leave for new opportunities or additional schooling (same goes for staff who don't have PhDs). Some departments have notoriously abusive senior staff (mental and verbal), and others that make sure you know that your role as junior staff is merely to assist them. While everyone knows this to be the case, it is not beneficial for morale - especially considering that frustration is often taken out on those who serve as the bulk of your research support. This being said, it really depends on your manager and the team of people you work with regularly.

Additionally, there seems to be disconnect and divide between HR and the various programs - which makes the hiring process disorganized and inefficient.

review_title: Nice people, terrible management in my Division
pros: A lot of great people who fight the good fight to create a quality product and work atmosphere.  Great location, decent pay, great benefits, and little perks like coffee and offices.
cons: Inept management in the Assessment division.  Not all of the managers, but several of the key players just create an environment that is sub-par.  The client side managers are the most unprofessional and disorganized I've dealt with and dump whatever then can last minute on the technical side of the house.  Tech managers are not allowed to push back effectively or reach a happy medium with efficient communication / workflow process's.  In fact there aren't process's at all here, at least not in the Assessment division.

review_title: The work can be great, but the company culture is cold.
pros: I love many of my colleagues.  Work can be demanding, but I wouldn't trade what I do for the world.  I feel I've grown a lot here.
cons:
The recent review mentioning the upcoming layoffs really made my blood boil.  The stock market is crashing, the President just stopped travel from Europe, the NBA is cancelling it's season,  the WHO just declared a pandemic, and guess what?  We've already laid off multiple staff this month and probably are going to lay off a bunch more.   Are we hurting for money?  Nope.  We evidently actually have a ton since selling a portion of our business.  Are we suspending executive bonuses?  Unlikely.  Could we wait a few months until everything calms down before laying off staff?  Easily.  

AIR simply does not care about the welfare of its employees.  Everyone is expendable.  How can we claim to help the underprivileged when we don't show compassion for our own staff?  With everything falling apart, employees at a company with deep pockets like AIR shouldn't have to worry about losing their job.  Yet, that's where we are.  Even those of use who have plenty of sold time are worried, because that has historically been no guarantee here.

job_title: Program Associate in Crystal City, VA
pros: Benefits. Flexible work arrangements. Plenty of food around.
cons: Poor management.  Few promotion opportunities.  Unclear mission.

review_title: Good colleagues and not enough focus on good management or management structures.
pros: Hands-on experience and some autonomy after finding a niche which may take years. Good and hard-working colleagues who are willing to help one another.
cons: Top heavy with hierarchical structure and big differences in pay scales. Projects understaffed so workload is heavy and often unpredictable. Many managers have no management skills and do not solve problems. Low salaries for entry level staff and raises minimal for those staff. Many burdensome organizational requirements. Not much interaction in the course of work day.

pros: I was surrounded by people who really valued my ideas even though I was in a lower position. They also really care about your professional growth within the company.  I enjoyed working with people who cared about what they did and shared their knowledge with others.
cons: I noticed that in order to get promoted, you HAVE to have a master's degree and you have to write a significant amount of grants. I think this is very common in the nonprofit space in DC, but I definitely see it as a con. Grant writing often takes away from the actual work that you want to do and needs to get done.

review_title: Ok first job out of college but DO NOT WORK IN ASSESSMENT
job_title: Psychometric Support/Research Assistant in Washington, DC
pros:
-Decent random perks: free bagels on Wednesdays, occasional free ice cream in the summer, company wide parties during holidays and other events with food and drinks (alcohol too)
-Decent learning events and some interesting research presentations
-Immediate coworkers were nice, Psychometricians were nice to work with too
-Casual dress code is nice
-Potential to travel with in the US
cons:
-No formal training, you learn as you go
-Takes a year to fully understand the job, but after that employees are not valued/compensated well enough for the knowledge they have
-These are high stakes tests and A LOT of responsibility is given to relatively new/young employees, with little supervision
-Not expected to stay in this position longer than 2 years, so there isn't investment in employees
-Not compensated appropriately for the amount of work and responsibility given
-Salary is not competitive
-Blatant favoritism by some directors
